item.title: Drag 'N Drop 60th Edition
item.description:
Drag ’N Drop 60th Edition
Out Friday 30th January 2026 – Drag ’N Drop 15i2

Drag ’N Drop is a quarterly magazine for RISC OS users, mainly the Raspberry Pi series of machines but much will be relevant to all users and programmers. It comes in PDF format (download).

Drag ’N Drop is an accessible publication focusing on having fun whilst learning how to program with your RISC OS machine.

It costs just GBP4.50, or GBP5.50 with a Zip file of programs typed-in and ready to run. You can try before you buy with free sample editions available for instant download.

Volume 15 Issue 2 is out now, with the issue already emailed out to subscribers.

In this issue:

News and Apps – All the latest in the world of RISC OS with details of where you can get new and updated free and commercial RISC OS software.

Beginner’s Pages – New to RISC OS? Don’t know your adjust from your select? Wonder how to type in a BBC Basic program? Check out our newbie pages.

Cover Story – Learn all about the Bezier and de Casteljau world of curves with a type-in RISC OS Drawfile processing application which approximates curves with straight lines.

Drawfiles on the BBC – Program which allows RISC OS Drawfiles to be plotted on 8-bit BBC micro and Electron computers. Full listing.

Coffee Break – Another Impression tip, this time how to create dropped capitals for attractive layouts on your DTP pages.

Big Dummies C – We get going with Wimp programming in C with the SWI library on RISC OS, learn about hexadecimal notation and tackle arrays. With type-in demo C program.

Compute Module 4 – Not quite a RISC OS laptop but a very portable native RISC OS machine. Full description of what’s involved with the setup which has the Compute Module 4 at its heart.

RISC OZ – Pesky is back home and guides us through moving text from one icon to another in another foray into RISC OS Wimp programming.

Hugh Bowman PI – A high-calibre sleuth is looking for a partner to investigate cases, we find out what’s involved with a review of AMCOG’s latest game.

Sample and buy your copy of Drag N Drop at www.dragdrop.co.uk.

item.title: Recovering a RiscOS Disk
item.description:
Just for future reference. All the issues I was seeing with the RiscPC boot were due to the monitor I was using failing to sync to the RiscPC video output. It simply showed a blank screen.

I got round this using an old multi-sync monitor that could sync down to the 640×350 that the RiscPC seemed to be defaulting to. It could also cope with 56Hz screen refresh that seems to get set at 640×400, again something my modern LCD panel would not sync too.

Once I got a signal I was able to configure the monitor and sort out the various disk issues. As others have said before the absence of !Boot doesn’t stop the machine booting.

item.title: 20 Years of MUG - 4th February 2026
item.description:
Midland User Group (MUG) – 20th anniversary celebration.

On Wednesday 4th February 2026 MUG will be celebrating 20 years since the first meeting of some RISC OS enthusiasts was held in Robin Edwards home in Blackwell.

These included, in addition to Robin Edwards, Dr Pete Borcherds, John Rickman, Doug Webb, David Mullard and Chris Dale.

At that first meeting it was decided to set up MUG and to to hold meetings every other month of the year.

The group quickly expanded to hold meetings at the Methodist Hall in Blackwell.

At the end of 2006, MUG helped the ARM Club with its Christmas show at Featherstone.

Over the course of the last 20 years MUG have held some 16 RISC OS based shows, including that first one, at various venues.

These include the first show run entirely by the club at the Heritage Motor Centre in Gaydon in 2007.

MUG shows have also been held at Birmingham University Guild of Student 2008 – 2009, Kenilworth 2010 – 2014, at the Recursion Fairs 2015-2018, virtually from 2022-July 2023 and the last, to date, in person MUG RISC OS Xmas Market in December 2023.

In addition to those events many MUG members have been regular trippers to the other RISC OS shows that have been held around the UK over the years.

MUG would like to thank members past and present, remember those who are no longer with us, and to thank the many RISC OS related companies and individuals that have made the last 20 years of RISC OS so memorable.

To commemorate the event MUG will be holding a celebratory meal in Kenilworth.

On behalf of the MUG membership.

More information about MUG

item.title: MuView and rendering PDF pages
item.description:
I’ve been experimenting with !CompoScripting it, and also have downloaded the mutool and Image Magik packages. Also been experimnting with IM on Linux. (One aim has been to generate a Composcript that analyses the page’s colourisation before applying an appropriate correction.

I’m also trying to work out how the RO !MuTools + IM can be used.

Some PDF pages do show browning of the text. But others really seem to have black text. FWIW with experiments to just the screen ‘cast’ I’d say you need about about a 20% saturation diff between RGB components to get a clear brown. And the black text in many scans seems of squash this in many cases. Varies from scanned magazine/book to another.

So one of the points I want to cover is have the prog analyse the stats of a page to show the stats how the frequency of RGB components vary with the level of each component, etc. Then have this control the ‘clean up’ to get optimum black ink on white paper for the output.

If I can do this I can do what I did for some earlier uses of running ‘C’ progs with CompoScript t get results… then write it up for Archive magazine.

BTW the newer versions of Compo are worth getting. They’d rather more powerful than one from 2008! Again IIRC I wrote about this for Archive. If you read that you may recall, for example, the script + ‘C’ prog that generates plots of E-field patterns around simple antenna systems, etc. Cane be found on the web as well.

TBH these days, though, I’m old, slow, and have 24/7 ‘carer’ duties. Plus have a poorer memory. So welcome help!

item.title: Rasberry Pi - which is best in 2026?
item.description:
Has anyone set up a dual boot linux / riscos on the pi? (e.g. using PINN)

PINN may not be your best starting point.

  1. RISC OS, when booting from SD, wants a very specific partition layout. NOOBS (and its successor PINN) can achieve this if RISC OS is the first OS to be installed, but there is a significant risk that installing a second OS on the same SD card could prevent RISC OS from working thereafter. For NOOBS this was a show-stopper: the situation may have improved with recent PINN releases but I have not checked.
  2. PINN will be installing an older version of RISC OS (5.28) which comes with old firmware that does not support recent hardware revisions of the Pi 4 or Compute module 4.

An alternative (hardware-based) method is to use a switch wired to one of the GPIO pins that config.txt can use to select which OS to boot. It might look something like this:

[gpio21=0]
        kernel=riscos.img
        cmdline=riscos.txt
        
        [gpio21=1]
        kernel=kernel8.img
        cmdline=cmdline.txt

Other parameters may (nay, will) need moving to these new sections in config.txt.

For a worked example, see this post by Chris Hall

This is the technique used by RComp’s 4té and several offerings from RISCOSbits.

item.description: But why are you using OS_CallEvery? As Charles says above, if you want timed events in a Wimp application, use Null events from Wimp_PollIdle (or Wimp_Poll, depending on exactly what you’re doing) to provide them. That way, your application is only doing things when given control through the standard Wimp polling interface, which is far more likely to be the right way to do things.

item.title: New DME ExtTheme and Launchpad available for download and testing
item.description:
I’d agree with Martin. If you can’t figure out what a command does just be reading it in isolation (ie. without the help text) it is bad design. I know we used to have arcane commands with single-letter parameters, but that originated in the 1970s/80s. There’s no reason we can’t have clear terminology these days.

FWIW Acorn themselves said that in the mid 90s, at a developer meeting, “Don’t use generic terms if a more descriptive word is clearer” (or words to that effect) . I’d imagine that advice would be in the Style Guide too, but IIRC the original Style Guide pre-dated Acorn’s progress in the mid-late 90s.

item.description:
After installing RPiOS Trixie on the Pi400, setting its fixed IPv4 address, and turning Control Centre → Interfaces → VNC to ON, I find that Avalanche 0.28 doesn’t connect, giving the message ‘Server only offered unsupported authorisation method(s)’.

Can anyone suggest what tweak is necessary to establish the connection?

(RISC OS 5.31 21-Jul-2024 on a Pi CM4)

item.title: RISCOSbits Stock News
item.description:
RISCOSbits must announce the immediate discontinuation of their highly successful VENOM premium NVMe RISC OS computer system. The last remaining machine left HQ earlier this week, to a new home.

As part of the eulogy for VENOM, it’s worth noting that it has been our most successful machine to date, selling more than any other system we’ve produced, although our FAST NVMe systems are hot on the heels. This has been especially surprising given its relatively short lifespan, but has been due, in no small part, to our excellent FreeNVMe drivers, developed in conjunction with RISC OS Open and Stader Softwareenwicklung.

To mitigate the loss, we’ve introduced a couple of new systems to our website, to make amends. Well, more like one and a half!

The PLUS FIVE is an add-on for the DIY THREE to add a very capable Linux board to the system. Using the modular nature of the DIY THREE case, the PLUS FIVE literally builds onto the existing system to add a Compute Module 5, running at 2.3GHz, with a base spec of 4GB RAM and 64GB of eMMC storage (NVMe is also available as an option). This can then be used to create a very powerful interconnected hybrid RISC OS/Linux system in a particularly small and expandable modular machine. This will be available to existing DIY THREE users for £169.

The is a full kit and caboodle of a DIY THREE and a PLUS FIVE is now also available, in the form of the new STACKER DIY kit. For just £369, you get the whole machine in one super compact case. For an extra £30, we can put it all together for you, with no DIY required!

Please check out our DIY pages for details of what the PLUS FIVE and the STACKER can do. There’s a user-written review and build article in the current issue of Archive too.

As part of the process of updating the RISCOSbits website to reflect this, we have also taken the difficult decision to begin to reflect the current changes in memory prices that are hitting hard across the whole computing world. As an example, 1TB NVMe drives have more than doubled in price in the last few months, and even the Raspberry Pi Foundation have had to increase the price of their boards and drives as a result. For several months, we have been able to use existing stock to offset and absorb the price increases, but stock is dwindling and the cheaper suppliers are running dry.

We are proud to be open and honest about our prices and publish them on our website for all to see, allowing customers to get an idea of the excellent value of our systems when making a decision about their next RISC OS machine, so the eagle-eyed amongst you will have noticed that we’ve had to change some prices over the festive period. But we still managed to offer a highly successful Christmas Cracker to quite a few new customers!

If you’re in the market for a new RISC OS machine, sometimes the early bird catches the worm! If you’re holding out for the next round of Show Prices, we may not be able to offer the high discounts you’ve come to expect.

The good news on NVMe pricing is that we’re trying to hold our prices as low as we can, and are managing to absorb some of the price rises, or ‘split the difference’ where we can’t hold them fast. But this won’t last for long and forecasters are currently predicting prices may continue to rise, possibly well into 2027.

Rest assured that the most up-to-date prices shown on our website will always be the best we can offer, without hidden surprises.

This has been especially surprising given its relatively short lifespan, but has been due, in no small part, to our excellent [FreeNVMe drivers](https://www.riscosbits.co.uk/nvme.htm), developed in conjunction with [RISC OS Open](https://www.riscosopen.org/content/downloads/raspberry-pi) and [Stader Softwareenwicklung](http://www.stader-softwareentwicklung-gmbh.com.de/indexE.htm).
To mitigate the loss, we’ve introduced a couple of new systems to our website, to make amends. Well, more like one and a half!
The [PLUSFIVE](https://www.riscosbits.co.uk/plusfive.htm) is an add-on for the [DIYTHREE](https://www.riscosbits.co.uk/three.htm) to add a very capable Linux board to the system. Using the modular nature of the DIYTHREE case, the PLUSFIVE literally builds onto the existing system to add a Compute Module 5, running at 2.3GHz, with a base spec of 4GB RAM and 64GB of eMMC storage (NVMe is also available as an option). This can then be used to create a very powerful interconnected hybrid RISC OS/Linux system in a particularly small and expandable modular machine. This will be available to existing DIYTHREE users for £169.
The is a full kit and caboodle of a DIYTHREE and a PLUSFIVE is now also available, in the form of the new [STACKERDIY](https://www.riscosbits.co.uk/stacker.htm) kit. For just £369, you get the whole machine in one super compact case. For an extra £30, we can put it all together for you, with no DIY required!
![](https://www.riscosbits.co.uk//ROOL/Stacker.jpg)
Please check out our [DIY pages](https://www.riscosbits.co.uk/diy.htm) for details of what the PLUSFIVE and the STACKER can do. There’s a user-written review and build article in the current issue of [Archive](https://www.archivemag.co.uk) too.
As part of the process of updating the RISCOSbits website to reflect this, we have also taken the difficult decision to begin to reflect the [current changes in memory prices](https://www.tomsguide.com/computing/ram-prices-are-exploding-heres-why-and-everything-you-need-to-know-about-surviving-ramageddon) that are hitting hard across the whole computing world. As an example, 1TB NVMe drives have more than doubled in price in the last few months, and even the Raspberry Pi Foundation have had to increase the price of their boards and drives as a result. For several months, we have been able to use existing stock to offset and absorb the price increases, but stock is dwindling and the cheaper suppliers are running dry.
We are proud to be open and honest about our prices and publish them on our website for all to see, allowing customers to get an idea of the excellent value of our systems when making a decision about their next RISC OS machine, so the eagle-eyed amongst you will have noticed that we’ve had to change some prices over the festive period. But we still managed to offer a highly successful [Christmas Cracker](https://www.riscosopen.org/forum/forums/1/topics/20169) to quite a few new customers!
If you’re in the market for a new RISC OS machine, sometimes the early bird catches the worm! If you’re holding out for the next round of [Show](https://www.riscosnorth.uk) Prices, we may not be able to offer the high discounts you’ve come to expect.
The good news on NVMe pricing is that we’re trying to hold our prices as low as we can, and are managing to absorb some of the price rises, or ‘split the difference’ where we can’t hold them fast. But this won’t last for long and forecasters are currently predicting prices may continue to rise, [possibly well into 2027](https://www.tomsguide.com/computing/theres-just-not-enough-supply-to-go-around-micron-believes-ram-shortage-wont-improve-until-2028-at-least-until-the-ai-demand-starts-to-fade-away).
Rest assured that the most up-to-date prices shown on our [website](https://www.riscosbits.co.uk) will always be the best we can offer, without hidden surprises.

item.title: Any possibility of Bush IBX settop (Lazarus) being released?
item.description:
Hi. I’m new here, and to RISCOS. I know this is a very old post to be replying to but I’m at my wits end trying to get to a desktop on a Bush IBX 100 set top box. I followed the instructions at the link that Rick Murray posted here and that I’ve found I believe on Chris Sawer’s website. I see it worked for you Rick but I’ve been going around in circles and whilst I’m almost there, I just cannot get the filer to run. I have pics of what I’m seeing but I don’t seem to be able to add them to this reply. The box is booting off the zip drive but as it boots I get the following messages:
File Filer:Templates not found
File Pinboard:Messages not found
File Filer_Run not found (presumably because the filer module has not loaded correctly so it doesn’t know what Filer_Run means)

I then get to a desktop with the task manager (the green acorn icon) and the display manager showing on the taskbar (pinboard?) but no filer window open and no drive icons showing. I can get to the command line by pressing the menu button on the acorn icon and choosing commands but if I try "filer_opendir IZIpFS::ZIP.$.Apps for example I just get “use *Desktop to Start the filer”. So it seems the filer module just does not load even though some things like the display manager do. I extracted the modules from the OS 3.7 roms running on an emulator on a PC using !zap. I then zipped them up with !zipEE, transferred them to a raspberry pi running risc OS which can read acorn formatted zip discs with a USB zip drive, transferred them to the drive that way, and then I use a parallel port zip drive to boot the IBX box. Phew! As I say I have pictures if there’s an easy way for me to send those. If anyone has any theories as to why this isn’t working for me I’d be eternally grateful. I followed the instructions at this link:

https://heyrick.eu/assembler/resources/stbgadt.html

Cheers,
Andrew.

item.title: Hard Disk support
item.description:
You’re not being daft at all — this is one of those long-standing RPCEmu oddities that never really got a clean public explanation.

Short version: yes, a fix was discussed and partially prototyped back around 2011–2012, but it was never merged, and hard-disk support for RO5 remains deliberately disabled in RPCEmu.

A bit more detail:

RPCEmu’s hard-disc emulation was written to match RISC OS 4.x behaviour on the Risc PC. RISC OS 5 changed some low-level assumptions around disc drivers, timings, and error handling. When people tried RO5 HDD images, it exposed bugs in RPCEmu’s IDE emulation — data corruption, https://tropical-casino.com/ bad geometry reporting, and subtle filesystem breakage rather than clean crashes. That’s why the support was disabled rather than left “use at your own risk”.

The fix you’re remembering was essentially a workaround that made RO5 mount an image, but it didn’t fully solve the corruption issues. From the maintainer’s point of view at the time, half-working storage emulation was worse than none, so it never went upstream.

As for how it’s disabled: you’re right, it’s not in the ROMs. RPCEmu checks the OS version it thinks it’s running and refuses to attach IDE devices for RO5 builds. It’s done in the emulator logic rather than the filesystem layer, which is why it’s not obvious at first glance in the source.

Could you enable it locally? Yes — people have done so by removing or bypassing the RO5 checks — but it’s risky. You may get something that appears to work and then quietly corrupts the image. That’s the big reason it hasn’t been officially re-enabled.

Posting an incorrect statement on the internet wins again! Thanks @Piers.

With -C opt-level=3 there’s no stack used at all, even if I make the code a little more practical. There are a lot of nops, because the parameter to writec is already in r0.

@Paolo, When I try to install with rustup target add armv4t-none-eabi I get

error: toolchain ‘stable-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu’ does not support target ‘armv4t-none-eabi’; did you mean ‘armv7a-none-eabi’?

#![no_std]
        #![no_main]
        
        use core::arch::asm;
        use core::arch::naked_asm;
        use core::panic::PanicInfo;
        
        // pub extern "C" to allow the naked asm to call main (with a stack).
        #[no_mangle]
        pub extern "C" fn main() {
          for c in "Hello world!\n".bytes() {
            writec( c );
          }
        }
        
        #[panic_handler]
        fn panic_handler(_p: &PanicInfo) -> ! {
          loop {};
        }
        
        fn writec( c: u8 ) {
          unsafe {
            asm! ( "mov r0, {0}\n svc 0", in(reg) c );

              "\n svc 0x40",

item.title: Paint sprite dragging
item.description:
Ok, so it’s an option. It’s still stupid, because it means that you’re going to get crashes unless the theme author is continually keeping up with what is in the ROM. The user is forced to choose between turning an option on and having crashes when they upgrade or at random times because a theme author missed something. If a given user who was using one theme happily switches to another that they downloaded, the system may crash in odd places just because a sprite was missing in the older theme.

There’s really no justification for that sort of behaviour. If someone can explain why an option which is actively dangerous to unaware users exists, I’d love to hear it, but I genuinely cannot think of one.

item.title: Updating Submenu Dialogue Boxes
item.description:
I have a feeling that I might be missing something obvious here…

I have a dialogue box as a submenu (a program information window), which has a toggle size icon so that the user can expand it to read additional details about the application. This works fine.

However, it would be nice if it could always open in the small state, to be a little bit tidier. With a normal window, this would just be a case of fiddling with the visible extent before calling Wimp_OpenWindow, but as a submenu, I can’t see how to do it.

I can set the submenu warning flag and catch Message_SubmenuWarning, but as far as I know that gives me the window handle and not the Open Window block. Similarly, Wimp_CreateSubmenu doesn’t take anything but the handle, so I can’t mess with the visible area before creating the dialogue on screen.

Sitting on Open Window events for the dialogue suggests that the application doesn’t receive one until the window is moved, not when it initially opens – so that doesn’t appear to help either.

Is there any way to achieve what I’m trying to do? Or is it a case of “I wouldn’t start from here”, and I need another approach to displaying the additional info (or just live with the toggled state persisting between visits)?

item.title: 'Mailbox is full' phishing puzzle
item.description:
I received an email yesterday saying:
==>
This message was created automatically by mail delivery software.

A message that you sent could not be delivered to one or more of its
recipients. This is a permanent error. The following address(es) failed:

info@theworkshopseries.co.uk LMTP error after RCPT TO:<info@theworkshopseries.co.uk>: 552 5.2.2 <info@theworkshopseries.co.uk> Mailbox is full / Blocks limit exceeded / Inode limit exceeded

Reporting-MTA: dns; s3161.fra1.stableserver.net

Action: failed
Final-Recipient: rfc822;info@theworkshopseries.co.uk
Status: 5.0.0
….
<==
It is lying, because my message did get through to the intended recipient, who said that his mailbox
was certainly not full. Now I have heard of these ‘Mailbox full’ phishing scams. But the links in this
message appear to be harmless. I presume that the scam’s method relies on inserting malware into a
computer to take note of the sender-addresses of emails arriving in the inbox. I had used Plusnet’s
webmail to send my original email, using the Chrome browser, so I do not think there is any malware
inserted at my end. So no harm done. But is my diagnosis correct? Should I be warning
info@theworkshopseries.co.uk that his computer may have been compromised?

item.description:
It shows “system started to shut down due to auto poweroff time up”

Just putting that phrase into google comes up with this as the second link.

2019 thread https://community.synology.com/enu/forum/1/post/126798

“I had the same issue and I just found what was the root cause in my case.

In “Hardware and Power” —> “HDD Hibernation” I had options “Enable advance HDD Hibernation” and “DS will enter standby via WOL after the HDD has hibernated” both checked.

This caused the NAS to power off, or maybe just to enter standby, but it did not wake up by itself, simply accessing the storage of through the web interface. I removed the “enter standby” flag and everything works fine for me now."

item.title: Sponsorship for 64-bit work
item.description:
Hiya,

There’s been a little bit of discussion about how people who are not technical can contribute towards work. One of the ways that has been suggested has been to provide donations towards people or that work. To try to provide a mechanism for this, I’ve decided to use the GitHub Sponsorship button.

On many of my GitHub projects, including the general `riscos64-status` project (https://github.com/gerph/riscos64-status), there is a Sponsor button. This will take you to https://github.com/sponsors/gerph/ where you can provide a sponsorship.

Providing sponsorship will encourage more development and tools for this project.
If you feel that the things that I’m doing and the work towards RISC OS 64 is valuable, please feel free to sponsor me!

item.title: Weird issue setting up printers
item.description:
In case it matters, StrongED on the working machine is 4.68f12, while on the newer one it is 4.70a15, Has printing changed there?

Firstly, do you mean 4.68f2 (last version of 4.68) or 4.69f12?

I’ve compared the printing code in 4.69f14 vs 4.70a20 and there aren’t that many differences. There’s some changes to how headers and footers are handled, and changes to make the print dbox override of the mode font height/width work.

If you’re using headers/footers then try turning them off and see if that helps.

ISTR an earlier report of PS3 issues but I can’t find that right now. Anyway, try printing with the PS2 driver, if possible. That will show if there is an issue with PS3 or if it’s a more generic problem.

item.title: Iyonix and the rest of my Risc OS collection
item.description:
Firstly, don’t tick “act as IP router”. If you fill in anything in the Routing window, only put the address of your router – leave everything else blank. If using DHCP, leave everything blank/unticked.

For IP address, either use DHCP (no options) or static (fixed) IP address within same range as router (eg. 192.168.8.100). Netmask of 255.255.255.0 Note that not many routers use 192.168.8.x so you might want to confirm that. 192.168.1.x or 192.168.0.x are more common.

For Host names, put hostname (eg. iyonix) in first box.
If using DHCP leave rest unticked/blank.
If not using DHCP, put something in domain (must have a dot in it) such as .nom or .home or a full domain if you have one (eg. riscos.com). For primary DNS, put address of router. For secondary address put 1.1.1.1 (Cloudflare) or 8.8.8.8 (Google).

Set/Save etc. Don’t forget to reboot.

If this doesn’t work, be aware that one of the first signs of a failing Iyonix PSU is the network port failing. USB ethernet is possible on RISC OS – stick to USB 2 adapters though, ideally with ASIX AX88772 chipset. Not every ROM has EtherUSB in ROM though.

RISC OS cannot use USB soundcards at all without a custom ROM. Even then, it can’t use it system-wide, only via specific software.

Finally, be aware that Iyonixes are amongst the more troublesome machines to keep going (see Martin Eastwood’s problems). You may be better off with a cheap Raspberry Pi to play around with – it will likely give you better compatibility with old games etc via !ADFFS and the AnyMode module.

item.title: Pre-order Voices From A Future Passed
item.description:
For those who enjoyed Rob Napier’s talk at ROUGOL last month, and those who missed it but were also excited to read the full history of Acorn, here’s a message from Rob about progress on publication of his book:

Over the holiday break, VOICES FROM A FUTURE PASSED has moved toward publication.

I am cautiously confident that it will be released on 1 March online through Amazon and through some bookshops and possibly some museum shops.

I have set up an information site at www.doitonce.net.au . It gives an outline of the book and a campaign to donate part of the sale price to museums. Please visit the site for details.

If you would like to pre-order or to contact me, just send me a message from there. I try to respond to everyone within one business day.

My HTML skills are a bit rusty and I’ve not managed to get too excited about current web design trends. If anyone has any comments/feedback, I’d be happy to receive your advice. That said: Please be gentle.

All the best
Rob Napier
-———-

item.title: App locations inside !Boot
item.description:
I’m beginning to delve into the murky innards of !Boot, with a view to extending the Clarity theme to the various default apps within it, including Configure. Presently, the sprites in the Clarity theme are installed with a simple Boot merge, with the new files all added into !Boot.Resources.!ThemeDefs.Themes.Clarity. This ensures that the sprites used by the Wimp, plus the icons used for the ROM Apps, are replaced.

If I also want to replace the icons used for the various !Boot apps (!Scrap, !System, etc), then I’m assuming that I can use the same Boot merge to add the required sprites into their various application directories (ie, !Boot.Resources.!System.Themes.Clarity, etc). This does assume that those application directories never move around – is that something I can rely on?

Similarly, the icons for the Configure app aren’t all in the same place. On RO5.31, most are in !Boot.RO500Hook.Res.Configure, but the Internet configuration seems to live in !Boot.Resources.Configure. Again, can I rely on these locations staying consistent, and use a Boot merge to add new sprites into their respective app directories?

I’m aware that there are theme manager applications in development, such as ExtTheme, that will probably be able to handle all this with a bit more aplomb, but I’m hoping to keep the basic distribution of Clarity as simple as possible – just an iconset that can be copied over !Boot with the various components dropped into the right places.

item.title: Live Coding with Gerph, Sunday 4th January at 1pm UK time.
item.description:
A bit of a scattered day today. I had fixed PicoC so that it could handle the _IN() and _OUT() macros, but somehow broke _OUTR() so the testing got a little distracted. However, the SWIs all seem to work on RISC OS 64, and so I moved on to replacing the data blob for the CPU registers descriptions with one that can be generated. We now have some Python code that builds the data that these tables use, which will make it a lot easier when we need to replace them with a different platform (or update them!).

Hopefully that was interesting to people. I also showed off the hotkey lookup in the editor as well – pressing shift-ctrl-h opens a Chrome Window with the relevant RISC OS documentation in. Pretty simple to do with all the other work that’s gone before, but I finally got around to doing it.

With that, I think I’m done on what I want to do on the Kernel Introspection for now – it’s stubbed well enough. I think next week, I think I’m going to have a look at FSCommands, unless anyone wants to jump in and ask for one of the other components…

Most of Phase 1 is complete (https://github.com/gerph/riscos64-status/wiki/Phase-1) but Phase 2 has lots of things in it (https://github.com/gerph/riscos64-status/wiki/Phase-2).

item.title: Using EX0 and EY0 for higher definition
item.description:
There are a quite a few things that don’t take into account the screen scaling when using EX0 EY0. The mouse pointer is one of them.

The OS does scale the mouse pointer for the eigen factors, witness changing to a EX1 EY2 mode. The issue is that a number of APIs assume no more than 32×32 hardware cursor (probably arising from VIDC, but I think some other graphics controllers have that limit too) so for example when you try to scale ptr_default which is 22 pixels high at EX1 EY1 you’d get 44 pixels at EX0 EY0 and the bottom 12 pixels are cropped off. The hourglass with percentage is taller still.

So your options are:

  • Live with the cropped pointer. Result: at least it’s proportionally the right size compared with everything else
  • Fudge it by using the 12×22 pixel pointer sprite in the Wimp’s Sprites11 file, this is what Castle opted to do with the Iyonix and that’s spread to some of the other themes. Result: at least it’s not cropped, just a bit teeny tiny
  • Roll up your sleeves and ripple the planned API changes through all the bits of low level graphics drivers which assume 32×32. Result: not cropped and correctly scaled on hardware that can do bigger overlays
item.source:markdown:
> There are a quite a few things that don’t take into account the screen scaling when using EX0 EY0. The mouse pointer is one of them.
The OS _does_ scale the mouse pointer for the eigen factors, witness changing to a EX1 EY2 mode. The issue is that a number of APIs assume no more than 32×32 hardware cursor (probably arising from VIDC, but I think some other graphics controllers have that limit too) so for example when you try to scale ptr\_default which is 22 pixels high at EX1 EY1 you’d get 44 pixels at EX0 EY0 and the bottom 12 pixels are cropped off. The hourglass with percentage is taller still.
So your options are:
- Live with the cropped pointer. Result: at least it’s proportionally the right size compared with everything else - Fudge it by using the 12×22 pixel pointer sprite in the Wimp’s Sprites11 file, this is what Castle opted to do with the Iyonix and that’s spread to some of the other themes. Result: at least it’s not cropped, just a bit teeny tiny - Roll up your sleeves and ripple [the planned API changes](/wiki/documentation/show/Proposed%20GraphicsV%20enhancements#TOC3.3) through all the bits of low level graphics drivers which assume 32×32. Result: not cropped and correctly scaled on hardware that can do bigger overlays

item.title: WROCC Meeting - Titanium at Ten - 7th Jan
item.description:
Wakefield RISC OS Computer Club

Meeting on Wednesday 7th January at 7.45pm

Titanium at Ten

Rob Sprowson of Elesar will celebrate the Titanium, the fastest RISC OS computer that’s been in production the longest. He will wind the clock back to the project’s origins, examining what worked and what didn’t. He will then spotlight several ideas for tapping into the currently unexploited processing power inside every box.

This ‘virtual’ meeting is open to all, and will take place using the Zoom conferencing service using our regular meeting credentials. Zoom invitations will be sent out ahead of the meeting, but only to those who email info2025@wrocc.org.uk to request one. If you would like to be part of the meeting (and don’t already have the link from a previous meeting or receive an invite in the next 24 hours as a member of WROCC), please RSVP — at the latest by the end of Tuesday 6th January (GMT). We email the links out on the morning of the meeting.

If you haven’t used Zoom before, we suggest that before Wednesday you try to join the Zoom test meeting at https://zoom.us/test on the device that you intend to use, in order to check that your system works OK. You will not require a Zoom account to take part.

Past Meetings

Videos of previous meetings can be found in our links to past meetings at https://www.wrocc.org.uk/meetings

Club Membership

Annual membership of WROCC is available for those living near and far at 10.00ukp per year.

Members receive:

  • A PDF newsletter with all the latest news and articles.
  • Entry to meetings.
  • Access to the WROCC Internet Discussion Forum.

For further information, please email info2025@wrocc.org.uk or visit the Club’s website at https://www.wrocc.org.uk

item.title: List of modules in C
item.description:
It relies on parts of the C library, which makes it problematic. StubsG is available as a binary and works – it should be usable as-is. Is there a particular issue you have found with the library?

The C library’s Apache licensed, so as long as you’re willing to make your code have a compatible licence it should be fine.

If it’s of interest, I have a (macOS/Linux) Makefile that fetches the source for stubs and builds three variants – 26bit, 32bit and vfp. The latter is a 32-bit stubs, patched automatically. It uses a python (extended) implementation of decaof to rename certain symbols in the symbol table in the .o files, and includes in the library veneers. These veneers export the original function name, and call the renamed functions. And they’re all made into a library with a python reimplementation of libfile. It sounds like it works very similarly to StubsG?

        *Set Debugger$DumpOptions -file annotated

item.title: RISC OS today and tomorrow: understanding behaviour and trade-offs
item.description:
I modified QEMU to load the “bios” (RISC OS ROM image) at 0 instead of 0×8000/0×80000. So it behaves like kernel_old=1 in config.txt (iirc).

#define FIRMWARE_ADDR_2 0 // 0x8000 /* Pi 2 loads kernel.img here by default */
        #define FIRMWARE_ADDR_3 0 // 0x80000 /* Pi 3 loads kernel.img here by default */

Plus a bunch of excessive logging, but that’s another matter.

If I were them, I’d have gone for a -preload file,address option, myself, to cover all eventualities like bios, kernel, inird, etc..

Just out of interest, do you do anything with ATAGs? I leave a gap, they’ll be readable, but I don’t scan them yet.

item.title: Is the system heap meant to be writable from BASIC?
item.description:
I was just thinking about somewhere safe for privileged code to write to for user mode code to read from and thought perhaps the system heap, since that’s where I thought the system variables are stored (and R3 returned from OS_ReadVarVal points to).

So I tried:

SYS"XOS_ReadVarVal", "*", 0, -1, 0, 0 TO ,,,V%

V% is set to &303FF7CC, in the system heap, not RMA (&20000000) and printing the string there shows “7backup$Dir”, as expected. What I wasn’t expecting was V%?5=42 to work, let alone change the name of the variable to “7back*p$Dir”!

Is this a limitation of recent MMUs?

item.title: Happy Christmas and New Year from all at R-Comp and ROD
item.description:
Firstly, I’d like to wish everyone a Happy Christmas and a super, RISC OS-filled 2026. Thankyou to eveyone for being part of the community this year, and for all your RISC OS related activity, support, developments, purchases and forum posts etc.

I’m now finishing for Christmas (well, it is nearly 4pm on Christmas Eve). The intention is to take a bit of a longer Christmas break as I’m absolutely exhausted from a non-stop year. I’ve been working weekends since the summer, and still not found time to celebrate my birthday from back in October! We’ve more-or-less cleared the decks in time for Christmas, so the plan is to take a rest until early Jan.

My intention is to return to work properly on Jan 12th, although I may well be checking email from the 7th onwards – if you can avoid sending tech support emails until then, it’d be appreciated.

In the meantime, Plingstore will continue to operate, although please be patient as I’ll likely only be approving orders every few days.

Christmas cards – I’m afraid we simply haven’t had a chance to do the usual Christmas Card send-out this year, so if you were expecting one and haven’t received, please don’t take it personally. Hopefully normal service will be resumed next year. I may try and slip a few out whilst listening to “Carols from Kings” this afternoon, but it is a wee bit late now.

Warrington Show (RISC OS North) is on Saturday, March 21st, 2026 – see www.riscosnorth.uk for more info. We’ve been slow on getting exhibitor invites out this year, but please pencil this date into your diary (the show has been paid for, so it is definitely happening). We hope to see you there if possible :)

I hope you all have a really nice Chirstmas period, and have exactly the balance of fun, friendship, food, relaxation and RISC OS that you wish for :)

Best wishes to everyone,

Andrew & all @ R-Comp and RISC OS Developments

item.title: BASIC and LOCAL DATA
item.description:
In PDP11 BASIC it took just one extra instruction to fix LOCAL DATA:continue tokenising:

jsr  pc,TokenSearch	; Search token table
        ;...
        bit  #2,r2		; Are we at the start of statement?
        bne  TokenWord1		; No, enter token/char
        bit  #16,r1		; Is this a pseudo-variable?
        beq  TokenWord2		; No, enter unchanged
        add  #&40,r0		; Convert token to command token
        .TokenWord1
        bic  #&40,r2		; *EXTRA* Middle of statement, don't turn tokeniser off
        .TokenWord2
        mov  r1,r2		; Copy new flags to current flags
        ;...

It looks to me that the ARM code would be similarly simple to update. I’ll have a look at it over Christmas.
item.source:markdown:
In PDP11 BASIC it took just one extra instruction to fix LOCALDATA:continue tokenising:
``` jsr pc,TokenSearch ; Search token table ;... bit #2,r2 ; Are we at the start of statement? bne TokenWord1 ; No, enter token/char bit #16,r1 ; Is this a pseudo-variable? beq TokenWord2 ; No, enter unchanged add #&40,r0 ; Convert token to command token .TokenWord1 bic #&40,r2 ; *EXTRA* Middle of statement, don't turn tokeniser off .TokenWord2 mov r1,r2 ; Copy new flags to current flags ;... ```
It looks to me that the ARM code would be similarly simple to update. I’ll have a look at it over Christmas.

item.title: GCCSDK Built with Nix!
item.description:
I’m pretty sure that I am the only person using GCCSDK via nix, but I’ve got some updates!
Firstly, I’m using it to compile for RiscOS from an Apple Silicon Mac! It will also definitely work on windows using WSL! So if you are using any of those platforms, great news! This will work a charm!

Next, I’ve managed to create an initial cross stdenv which means that it is much easier to use nix as the build system. The example flake is here:
https://github.com/yobson/riscos-nix/tree/main/example

Next steps will be building OSLib and others this way and move some things over from the auto builder. I also spotted the nordsoft compiler on GitHub (I don’t think it’s the one ROOL uses but will work for risc os), so I may give that the same treatment.

Either way, this is turning out to be a very nice way to bring building for risc os to 2025.

item.title: CRamFS
item.description:
I finally got around to trying this out on the RiscPC (using a StrongARM and RISC OS 5.30), and have got some initial numbers from m1time:

RamFS 2.33 (23 Nov 2020):

Save 1M * 1000: 8539 csec
Load 1M * 1000: 6131 csec

CRamFS + memmove:

Save 1M * 1000: 9370 csec
Load 1M * 1000: 7028 csec

CRamFS + BlockMove:

Save 1M * 1000: 9517 csec
Load 1M * 1000: 6346 csec

I’ve added a bunch of comments on the merge request of things that might help, but I currently don’t have any tools for getting more detailed benchmarks on the RiscPC. That said, it should be possible to get the performance roughly equivalent in C – the BlockMove function seems to be the only part that’s doing something complicated that would require assembly code for performance.

item.title: Obscure wimp sprites
item.description:
Some more thoughts on Paint, having been using it very heavily over the past few weeks:

  • The various bugs that used to affect various tools in the Sprite window seem to have been very effectively squashed. I don’t think I’ve had a single crash from that source over many hours of use.
  • The new outline font tool is great, as is the much better Paintbrush interface. Very nice work.
  • There’s a bug report (ticket 520) open on the file dragging/selection in the Spritefile window. This issue would be great to look at – it’s pretty annoying to drag a sprite into a file window and have it replace whatever is currently selected, even if the sprites have different names. When dragging dozens of files around, it’s very easy to overwrite stuff by mistake this way.
  • Relatedly, if you try to rename a sprite in a Spritefile window to one that already exists, Paint silently fails to rename it, rather than telling you why.
  • The only crashes I’ve had came when deleting a sprite from a Spritefile window. Annoyingly, I can’t reproduce this reliably. If I can find some way to reproduce this, I’ll file a ticket.

I’m not sure if the Bounty work is still current. If it is, then taking a look at some of these issues in the Spritefile window would be really useful. I think possible fixes here would be to:

  • Mimic the Filer’s selection behaviour, so that selecting sprites in one Spritefile window clears the previous selection in another window
  • Alternatively (or in addition), don’t overwrite selected sprites with different names when dragging sprite(s) into a Spritefile window, but just add the new sprites to the Spritefile
  • When a sprite or selection of sprites is dragged to a Spritefile window containing a sprite(s) with the same name, or the user tries to rename a sprite with a name already existing in the file, query the decision. Either halt it, or offer to skip/abort/overwrite.

In any case, congrats to Andy for all his hard work – the app has been really transformed.

item.description:

Fix for loads of halfword values not making use of unaligned LDR instructions when they are permitted by -memaccess +L41. This resulted in the halfword being formulated from two LDRB instructions which the register allocator did not expect, and R12 being wrongly reused in some small leaf functions.

item.title: Accessing ROOL Via Three Broadband
item.description:
You’re most likely on IPv4?

Very definitely on both IPv6 and IPv4. I was surprised when I tried a Three SIM and found it gave me an IPv6 address (not to be confused with what WiFi gives me!). The IPv6 support is the primary reason I moved (just a few days ago) from O2 to Three.

The killer test, which I’ve just repeated, is to access one of my IPv6-only sites from my phone after turning WiFi off. The web page and the site’s log both show the Three IPv6 address of my phone, which has a very different prefix from that given to me by WiFi.

item.title: RDPclient with Windows 10
item.description:
I’ve just had the same issue with RDPClient connecting to a new install of Windows 11 Professional 25H2.
There were some additional settings that I needed to change to get RDPClient to connect. (I was seeing the same “connection reset by peer error”)

1. Open GPEDIT.MSC
2. Expand Computer Configuration > Administrative Templates > Windows Components > Remote Desktop Services > Remote Desktop Session Host > Security
3. Change “Set client connection encryption level” to “LOW”
4. Change "Require use of specific security layer for remote (RDP) connections to “RDP”
5. Change "Require user authentication for remote connections by using Network Level Authtication to “DISABLED”
6. Reboot the PC

Obviously lowering the security defaults for Remote Desktop is a bad idea security wise, so use at your own risk!

item.title: Status update for RISC OS 64-bit work
item.description:
It’s been about 5 weeks since I did a status update on the 64-bit RISC OS work.

  • The Wimp Templates subcomponent was worked on as part of the Live Coding and is now complete – See https://github.com/gerph/riscos-wimp-templates for the details.
  • The `riscos64-status` repository has been updated with a few things:
    • `PicoC` is noted as a ported language.
    • `Lua` is noted as a ported language.
    • `TCC` is noted as a ported implementation of a C compiler.
    • `GCC` was removed from the ported implementations (it’s not ported, but is usable to build for RISC OS 64, and had been misplaced).
    • `Pascal` is noted as a ported language (using the P2C tool).
    • `Rust` is noted as having been prototyped for use with RISC OS 64.
    • All the feature documents for component now include completion percentages on their pages.
  • The `Kernel: Modules` subcomponent had been started.
  • The `EvaluateExpression` module has been stubbed.
  • The `IIC` module has been stubbed.
  • The `OSSWIs` module has been stubbed.
  • The hourglass maker has been ported to RISC OS 64. See https://github.com/gerph/riscos-hourglass-maker for details.
    • The module can be found in the `riscos64-status` repository as with many others.
  • The Pascal-to-C implementation is being worked into the build environment.
  • I presented the general status of RISC OS 64 work to ROUGOL, and the presentation is available on YouTube and through my presentation site. See https://presentations.riscos.online/pyromaniac4/index.… for video, slides and resource links.
  • RISC OS Pyromaniac screenshots and videos were updated with the details of the changes and work towards 64-bit. See https://pyromaniac.riscos.online/examples.html#talk2025 for images and videos.
  • The RISC OS 64-bit C library has been updated with better handling of linking hidden and internal symbols, and `fgetc` now works properly. See https://github.com/gerph/riscos64-clib for details.
  • `objasm2gas` tool has been updated to handle `:INDEX:` and `:BASE:` (as well as the `@` metavariable), and fix problems with field mappings using registers not being calculated as expressions.
  • The `Kernel: Introspection` component will be the next live coding project.

Anyhow, that’s where things are for me. You can always follow the repositories to see what’s being done.

As usual, if anyone wants to contribute to these, please speak up.

item.title: Setting up a new monitor
item.description:
Perhaps a useful facility for RISC OS would be to be able to substitute a user-supplied EDID definition block during boot (pre-desktop).

You can already do that. EDID blob files (with filetype &F76) can be used in all the places an MDF can – you can drag and drop onto Display Manager’s icon bar icon, or *LoadModeFile it, and the monitor list shown in !Configure can chew them too if placed somewhere in the BootResources:Configure.Monitors to be scanned with the others.

item.title: Ilitek-tp touchscreen
item.description:
So I have this interesting device – it is a Raspad 3 (combined with a RP4b 4GB).
I am sure i recently got it to boot RISC OS 5.31 but it hasn’t done so again today so will have to play with it more. When it did boot the screen worked but not the touchscreen function (it’s RISC OS) – the touch screen works in Raspberry Pi OS and identifies as a ilitek-tp screen working on HDMI.
Has anyone got any idea if this can be made to work with RISC OS.
Apparently the ilitek-tp screen is a capacitive type device.
Also don’t think the USB ports on the main board (not the Rpi4) were working with RISC OS but let’s start with the screen.
If i can’t get it working with RISC OS then it may get used as a Pi-Core music player.

item.title: Proivde Simple 3D api to basic?
item.description:
RISC OS already support OpenGL. This wish list item would be to provide a simple module translating GL or VUlkan(?) calls to an appropriate SWI. in BASIC you would then do SYS “GLFunc”,“@”, PTR param_block.

Where GLFunc gets 2 pointers, 1(string) to the name of OPenGL(ES) or Vulkan Function, and the second param being a sutiable width pointer to the parameter block.

Alternatively it would be nice to have some kind of native 3D api, that can be called directly from Basic.

item.title: A Puzzling Addition to the Platform
item.description:
With uncharacteristic speed following the release of Puzzles 1.00 for RISC OS, version 1.01 is now available to download from https://www.stevefryatt.org.uk/risc-os/games – copies can also be found on the PlingStore, and should appear in PackMan shortly.

The main changes from 1.00 are a few updates from the upstream – the user-facing ones are to the Dominosa, Mines and Undead games.

The RISC OS front end now supports the text_fallback() function, which allows it to make the characters in the top half of the current RISC OS character set available to games if they wish to make use of them. This improves the text display in a couple of the puzzles. If you’re playing Puzzles on a platform that doesn’t support the UCS lookup tables, or are using an alphabet that doesn’t have the desired glyphs in it, then games will continue to use plain ASCII as before.
item.source:markdown:
With uncharacteristic speed following the release of Puzzles 1.00 for RISC OS, version 1.01 is now available to download from [https://www.stevefryatt.org.uk/risc-os/games](https://www.stevefryatt.org.uk/risc-os/games) – copies can also be found on the PlingStore, and should appear in PackMan shortly.
The main changes from 1.00 are a few updates [from the upstream](https://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/puzzles/) – the user-facing ones are to the Dominosa, Mines and Undead games.
The RISC OS front end now supports the `text_fallback()` function, which allows it to make the characters in the top half of the current RISC OS character set available to games if they wish to make use of them. This improves the text display in a couple of the puzzles. If you’re playing Puzzles on a platform that doesn’t support the UCS lookup tables, or are using an alphabet that doesn’t have the desired glyphs in it, then games will continue to use plain ASCII as before.

item.title: Iris and Messenger Pro 9
item.description:
I… cough… insert a single SYS “WImp_Poll” command every 100th READ or WRITE, or every 100th iteration of huge nested loops, to make it multi-task. Real programmers will probably shout: “Eek!”, but well, it works.

That’s fine until the Wimp_Poll returns an event that you need to handle immediately… at which point, things can start to get very messy, very quickly… As soon as you start to add things like window redraw, a state machine hanging off Null events is often easier to make work. :-)

item.title: Hugh Bowman PI V1.14 Released - A new Original RISC OS Game!
item.description:
@AVB,

I wouldn’t bother. Pretty much every solution for running RISC OS applications supported sound. The ‘RISC OS On Linux’ project, totally understandably, hasn’t got around to that yet. And if you are just using typical desktop apps, then it’s no big deal. We are talking about one implementation here, with what, a handful of users. I’d be stunned if it was worth the effort.

Also, I think for most games, the sound is key too.

If anyone wants to spend time on it, I’d suggest a module which accepts the relevant SWIs/vectors/whatever for the sound APIs, and just does nothing with them. That would allow audio apps/games to start. In the future, some enterprising soul can figure out how to glue the module into talking to the Linux audio API.

item.title: Early ExtTheme almost ready for alpha testers
item.description:
To everyone interested,

I have completed testing the new Theme “Actuator” for my ExtTheme. At the moment, to load a new theme I am using CHris (Little Yellow Moon) original Theme Configure plug-in, but I need to rewrite that, because ExtTheme allow a use to customize a theme (and remembers the customizations between theme switching).

Check this link to have a look at which Themes are already available (there are more than the screenshots in the article), but this gives you an overview:

https://paolozaino.wordpress.com/2025/11/30/dme-projec…

Note for Chris and Martin:

I am trying to write some documentation, as soon as I am done I’ll figure out a way for you both to be able to install this and start playing with it.

Please DO NOT use your daily RISC OS system for these tests! I need to replace the Configure plugin and the update may leave stuff behind! So this is just to test your own themes.

I am planning a public beta for Christmas if I have enough time.

item.title: Live Coding with Gerph, Sunday 30th November at 1pm.
item.description:
Next week I’ll be finishing the font handling, and adding in some more test code. It should be relatively easy to do, I hope. That should make the component functional, and we can move on to something else.

I’m thinking that the next one to implement will be the FSCommands module. Largely it’s just an interface from the commands to the OS_FSControl calls, so it should be pretty trivial.

If anyone has any thoughts or suggestions, please drop a line, as these sessions are intended to be interactive and informative.

item.title: Frosted Icon Set for 2025
item.description:
Ok guys,

let me disable the wobbly stuff (there are quite a few, because I started to reverse engineer WTB patch if anyone remebers it, to add it to my ExtTheme and allow even more customizability), I’ll package it and give it to both of you for testing.

It should take me a few days max.

ExtTheme already has all your work Chris for your old Theme Manager, so you’ll need to create a theme file with all the configuration options like you did in the past. The Theme file format is identical (I kept the same format for compatibility with the past Themes made for your TM). There are more options now, and it does work fine with coloring the windows border (well it can do even more than that, and add size to the border too, but that size is one of the wobbly functions).

It also already includes all the features of ThemeDef from ROOL, and everything is rewritten in C (’cause some folks complained that DME Launchpad was written in BBC BASIC…).

I’ll need both your emails, please contact me at the link below, and as soon as I have disabled the things that makes RO unstable I’ll send you a PackMan package that should install both the Configure UI and the Theme actuator.

https://paolozaino.wordpress.com/contact/

A required note: This is alpha quality code, so there might be issues even with the unstable features disabled.

One of the funniest unstable feature is having the iconbar on the left (or right or top) of the screen (yes can do that too), it works, BUT it also duplicate the iconbar XD – I am still fighting with that one, so will be disabled.

item.title: London Show, Sat 25th October 2025
item.description:
No i think its been misunderstood, what im doing is seperate from anyone else, i wanted to do interviews at the London Show and record, but i was put off, then i was approached by ROD which indicated its something they wanted for north so i said i would look into it. Whoever is handling the theatre talks will be doing the same again.

That’s odd, because what you originally wrote – in response to perceived quality issues with the London theatre videos – was

I’m planning to go to the north show next year and upload videos, but mirror the presentations with a PIP approach to having the host in the talks.

which certainly read as if you were planning to video the talks. If not, then we have all indeed misunderstood1; in that case, apologies.

No one has said anything about taking over anyone’s job, Not that i knew that certain individuals had roles reserved to themselves.

They don’t. But common sense says that when you have a platform running off a limited pool of volunteers, and also have volunteers happily in place doing some roles, it’s generally best to see if new volunteers can take on roles that aren’t already being done. Instead of finding out that the volunteers who you’ve just displaced from constructive roles have little interest in doing something else and have just buggered off into the sunset taking their skills with them.

If the original volunteers are looking for a change of scenery, on the other hand, then go for it. Obviously.

I do think the idea of a video with little interviews where possible of attendees and possibly exhibitors if possible would maybe help encourage people is a good one as it could complement the theatre talks.

Indeed, although a small word of caution: it does need to be planned in advance (which can be before the show opens, if you’re not getting under people’s feet, or during the day), so that exhibitors know to expect an interview and don’t just have a live camera shoved in their face. Sorry, but the latter has happened before (as have other things that you might not expect – after many years exhibiting at events, I’ve learned the hard way that some corners of the RISC OS community are… odd). This may explain some of the cynicism being expressed. That’s also why recorded and edited is better than livestreamed: with the live option, some people may be unhappy with what gets out2.

1 or have been misdirected?

2 WROCC’s videos tend to be edited, I think. Usually just to remove the more blatant pauses and awkward bits, but sometimes to remove things that presenters have got cold feet over in the cold light of the next day.

item.title: Episode IV - A New Hope
item.description:
Not only did 1977 see the release of space opera Star Wars – A New Hope, but it was also a year famous for the release of Fortran 77, the follow up to Fortran IV and ’66.

Your compliance is imperative

Fortran is one of a family of imperative programming languages, and was originally short for Formula Translation. Finding applications in scientific fields such as modelling of weather systems, molecular structure, and of course calculating star ship propulsion vectors.


Image available as wallpaper from r33v01v3 via Steam

As described in our FAQ the imperative languages are in the class of languages that the Norcroft compiler supports, and we’ve long known from odd scraps of evidence such as the RISC iX User Guide that there was a Fortran version at one time which went alongside the C language we’re so much more familiar with.

With help from Codemist a search of their archives managed to locate a partial copy last worked on in the 1990s on a backup tape stowed inside an old R2-unit.

Joining the Fortran front end – the part of the compiler which deals with language specifics – with the rest of the contemporary tools creates the f77 compiler. In addition, a brand new 200+ page manual describes its use in detail, along with ANSI runtime library.
item.source:markdown:
Not only did 1977 see the release of space opera [Star Wars – A New Hope](https://www.disneyplus.com/en-gb/welcome/star-wars), but it was also a year famous for the release of Fortran 77, the follow up to Fortran IV and ’66.
### Your compliance is imperative
Fortran is one of a family of _imperative_ programming languages, and was originally short for **For** mula **Tran** slation. Finding applications in scientific fields such as modelling of weather systems, molecular structure, and of course calculating star ship propulsion vectors.
![Wireframe X-Wing](/images/risc_os_open/xwing.jpg)
Image available as wallpaper from [r33v01v3](https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1941346742) via Steam
As described in our [FAQ](/content/documents/dde-faq) the imperative languages are in the class of languages that the Norcroft compiler supports, and we’ve long known from odd scraps of evidence such as the [RISC iX User Guide](http://www.computinghistory.org.uk/det/34486/Acorn-RISC-iX-User-Guide/) that there was a Fortran version at one time which went alongside the C language we’re so much more familiar with.
With help from Codemist a search of their archives managed to locate a partial copy last worked on in the 1990s on a backup tape stowed inside an old R2-unit.
Joining the Fortran front end – the part of the compiler which deals with language specifics – with the rest of the contemporary tools creates the `f77` compiler. In addition, a brand new 200+ page manual describes its use in detail, along with ANSI runtime library.

item.title: Time to Update !Killer :)
item.description:
A few things in no particular order.

1) There was a security permissions “gotcha” that we’d not spotted that came in during a gitlab update a few months ago that was preventing the automatic git mirroring occurring for the TCP/IP 6 project. This has now been resolved, so the code should now auto-update between the internal project git and the ROD git. As a result, the missing 7.09 code is now present as expected.

2) AFAIK that auto-mirroring only applies to that specific project, and happens more-or-less in realtime, so should always reflect latest code. Those wishing to contribute should contact us for further info. Other project repositories work as you would normally expect.

3) Vprotect and Killer sources are now in the ROD git. However, they are not publicly visible due to concerns over security, and there not being enough remaining skilled coders to provide the necessary levels of peer review.

4) My goal would be for public binary builds to appear ASAP

5) Access to those git repositories is available on request, but it is likely we will vet applicants to at least some degree because of the sensitivity of the materials. We have already had one compelling offer to provide long term maintenance of this software, but I’m aware other work has been done and am keen to see all interested parties working together on this.

6) The hint about the Explore link was in the “Explore the github” but you can do so directly via https://gitlab.riscosdev.com/explore

7) Don’t expect to see the Vprotect/Killer projects in the public “explore” due to their sensitivity, until such time as releases are ready.

item.title: Why is ROOL doing this?
item.description:
Ok, so maybe ‘random’ wasn’t strictly accurate, what I really do is use the same one swi allocation that was ever even approximately mine every time I write a module. From memory this includes the original use, a podule rom board to boot NFS, A broken driver for DE600 parallel Ethernet interface, a dot1Q vlan encapsulation layer (also broken) a driver for a bbc Winchester or Filestore drive on a Arc 1MHze bus podule, or more recently a DCI 4 implementation of the DCI2 ip over econet encapsulation, so I think I will get away with it for a while yet.

Clearly a web site you make an account on, confirm you email, upload the !Allocate file, which at least proves you are reasonably ligit, and emails you back and displays on the web page, would be very much better.

item.title: Toolbox File Format
item.description:
Yes, though remember Gadget is a variable size depending on the gadget. The original Toolbox manual describes it the best as it highlights various pitfalls.

Set num_gadgets and they then go sequentially in the ‘data’ field. Each gadget has a size, which is (usually) the offset to the next gadget.

http://www.riscos.com/support/developers/toolbox/windo…
http://www.riscos.com/support/developers/toolbox/windo…

The pitfalls are that you shouldn’t assume the size of each header (ie. Window template or Gadget template) and instead use the offsets “The use of a body_offset field is to allow expansion in the header, without losing backwards compatibility.” Similarly ‘gadgets’ is an offset, in the Window template, and “type/size” has the gadget size in the gadget top two bytes (the second link above describes “type/size”).

For reading a file, you should handle the offsets properly, but the reality is they are just memory dumps of the C structures that have never changed size.

Annoyingly, it says “Note that for the gadgets listed below, the size is ‘built in’ to the Window module, and so the size can be set to zero…” which is ridiculous, so means you’ll have to hard-code the sizes for the original gadget set. I think you should use the built-in size if the value in the file is zero, and the value in the file if it’s non-zero.

item.title: RPCEmu inside Docker, using VNC
item.description:
The article today about using RPCEmu on macOS reminded me that I’ve not mentioned the Docker images for RPCEmu that I created some time ago since they were updated. It also made me finally add the automatic resizing and push a multi-arch image (coo, I can now do both ARM and AMD in the same image!).

To use…

        docker run -it --rm -p 5901:5901 -v $PWD:/riscos/Shared gerph/rpcemu-3.7

or

        docker run -it --rm -p 5901:5901 -v $PWD:/riscos/Shared gerph/rpcemu-5

then connect to the VNC server (with Screen Sharing, or some other client) at localhost:5901 and use the password password.

The current working directory is shared into $.Shared.

As this is a separate configuration, a clean system, and has access to the filesystem it’s really trivial to customise, or just use for running those odd things that you need now and then. And you can be sure that you’ve not broken the system as it’s exactly as distributed.

The disc image is as supplied by the easy start bundles, with tiny tweaks (removing the Acorn logo from the backdrop, changing the screen mode to be larger, and adding a module that resizes the X server on mode change). This also has the interesting side effect of making the system rather more useable when made full screen.

And of course, being docker, you can also run this on Linux and on Windows, and it’ll be pretty much the same.

Sources, as usual, are on GitHub – https://github.com/gerph/rpcemu-docker. You can see the startlingly dumb way that the screen resolution is communicated out of the emulator in the VNCResize module. It’s certainly enough to work on the simple mode changes.

item.title: Floating Point in C
item.description:
I’ve got the score up over 900k, and once over 1m, by giving it more registers – I chose to set the baseline to allow the output to run on a PiZero which only has 8 D VFP registers. But 8 D registers means (under AAPCS) none are preserved over a function call. Giving it more would clearly be more efficient, but limits the h/w it can run on. I see apcs-softpcs (which I copied for VFP init) requests 16 D registers.

Curiously, 4 saved D FP registers outperforms 6 or 7 saved (ie. in addition to the 8 D arg registers) – I’ll investigate more as that shouldn’t really happen. ARM’s Norcroft currently has a limit of 31 registers (int + FP), due to its impressive use of signed maths throughout, so I can’t easily use 8 + 8.

After a little bit of fiddling around … it now runs.

That’s quite neat. Potentially could be useful, in fact, since my regression test harness (running on unix) can’t execute any code under RISC OS, only check the disassembled output. I was pondering ELF output for a Pi, but I’ve done all the work on a Mac (hence RPCEmu, hence forgetting about unaligned memory).

Modern, mainstream browsers tend to block insecure links/content in secure pages.

Yay, fewer spamages. It’s literally a one-line python http.server running as a very restricted user as I couldn’t be bothered to setup up a web server, but probably should one day.

item.title: Keyboard layout and *configure country
item.description:
Looking at the RISC OS source, on reset the keyboard type is set to UK in KeyPostInit in Kernel/s/PMF/key. I have modified RISCOS.IMG so that this routine sets the type to USA instead of UK (by directly changing byte 0×458d4 of the RPi Stable 5.30 ROM image to 0×30, from 0×01 – there doesn’t seem to be any checksum on this binary image on the Pi).

As a workaround, this seems fine – now I have a default USA keyboard when booting directly to supervisor/BASIC.

item.title: Translating BASIC to C
item.description:
Long term readers of these fora may remember that I think Printer Manager is far too big to be extended to deal with IPP printers in its present BASIC form.

It occurred to me that it might be possible to translate it to C, in small increments, leaving it testable at all times, by translating bottom-up (i.e. replacing the lowest level functions and procedures first) and replacing them with calls to a module written in C. The module would only be needed until all the translation is done, by which time we’d have a complete translation into C that then would be converted from a module to an app.

Printer Manager is an enormous job to take on top-down, as nothing could be used until it’s all done. The way I’m suggesting would have something testable and usable (the ultimate test of testability!) at all stages.

Any thoughts?

item.title: Guide to Impression
item.description: The Guide to the Impression Suite now comes with a complete worked example of how to turn a document into a RindBind manual. It starts with an Impression Publisher document which is the original manual for Equasor, TableMate etc. that was originally created in Impression. The process to print that as a PDF, then to extract individual Draw files for each page from that PDF is described in detail with examples at each stage. Packaging this into a ‘RingBind’ file is also described in detail with all the files created at each stage provided. As RingBind reserves space for the Draw file data for four pages, each the size of the largest individual Draw file for a page, it makes sense to reduce the few largest Draw files to a resolution appropriate to screen display rather than printing. The process to do this is also described. A copy of MakeDraw is required.
